user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of detect_process_cpu_core_count:
```c
static unsigned int
detect_process_cpu_core_count (void)
{
  unsigned int num_proc_cpu_cores;
  unsigned int sys_cpu_cores;
  int res;

  sys_cpu_cores = get_cpu_core_count ();
  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count ();
  if (0 > res)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Cannot detect the number of logical CPU cores available "
             "for this process.\n");
    if (1 != sys_cpu_cores)
      printf ("Assuming all %u system logical CPU cores are available to run "
              "threads of this process.\n", sys_cpu_cores);
    else
      printf ("Assuming single logical CPU core available for this process.\n");
    num_proc_cpu_cores = sys_cpu_cores;
  }
  else
  {
    printf ("Detected %d logical CPU core%s available to run threads "
            "of this process.\n", res, (1 == res) ? "" : "s");
    num_proc_cpu_cores = (unsigned int) res;
  }
  if (num_proc_cpu_cores > sys_cpu_cores)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "WARNING: Detected number of CPU cores available "
             "for this process (%u) is larger than detected number "
             "of CPU cores on the system (%u).\n",
             num_proc_cpu_cores, sys_cpu_cores);
    num_proc_cpu_cores = sys_cpu_cores;
    fprintf (stderr, "Using %u as the number of logical CPU cores available "
             "for this process.\n", num_proc_cpu_cores);
  }
  return num_proc_cpu_cores;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I have reported every conditional branch and their bodies that could potentially be unreachable depending on the return values of the external functions (get_cpu_core_count and mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count) or on assumed invariants. These are the only places in the function where control flow can skip or enter blocks; they should be investigated to ensure none of them are provably unreachable under the project's assumptions.

Other fragments were not reported because they do not constitute unreachable code: variable declarations and simple assignments (sys_cpu_cores = get_cpu_core_count(); res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count(); num_proc_cpu_cores = ...), the final return, and the printf/fprintf calls themselves (outside the conditional branches already listed) are reachable as part of the listed branches. There are no statements after a return, no constant-conditional constructs, no dead labels/gotos, and no other obvious syntactic dead code in the function, so no further fragments need investigation for MISRA C Rule 2.1.
